page.title: 17EASTCOMBE 2
page.content: A hundred years ago there were three pubs. One called the Red Lion had a large statue of a red lion over its doorway (which still exists), and was supposed to get down for its dinner when the Baptist church clock struck twelve. For a period in the late 19th century there were two rival schools, supported by the Church of England and the Baptist Chapel which had political associations. The Liberal supporters were the largest in numbers having working traditions and thus had a bigger chapel and school. The present primary school is housed in the Baptist premises. The two schools combined in 1919 when school teachers were in short supply due to World War1 Travel used to be by donkey and trap or walk. Today most people travel by car. There is a limited bus service of one per day going in and out.
